Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I was in the middle of trimming Mrs. Lee’s fringe, the gentle hum of the salon blending with her soft chatter, when my phone buzzed in my apron pocket. I glanced at the screen—Mom. I let it go to voicemail, but a minute later, another call. My heart thudded. I excused myself, promising Mrs. Lee I’d be right back, and ducked into the break room. Mom’s voice trembled as she told me about Dad’s health scare, her words tumbling out, raw and scared. She needed me to listen, to reassure her, to be the daughter who could hold her together. But Mrs. Lee was waiting, trusting me to fix her fringe just right, to make her feel beautiful and heard. I could picture her in the chair, glancing at the clock, maybe wondering if she’d made me late for my next appointment. My hands shook as I tried to comfort Mom, but my mind kept darting back to the salon, to my client, to the professional I was supposed to be. I felt split in two, pulled by the need to be present for my mother and the duty to care for my client, both expecting all of me at once.
